author: Vanessa McGrady
title: Drink This Instead Of That: Better Wines For Your Buck
text:
Most of us have our go-to wines that we turn to for a particular dish or occasion, or as a gift we like to bring to dinner. But beware those comfortable and unexamined habits: you could be spending more than you need to, and when you’re on selection auto-pilot, you’re not expanding your knowledge or your palate.[caption id="attachment_453207716" align="" width="640"] Wines from the La Rioja region of Spain hold their own against more familiar varietals. Photo: CESAR MANSO/AFP/Getty Images[/caption]Sommelier Jörn Kleinhans is a certified specialist of wine, a contributor to the Wall Street Journal and the Robb Report, and he owns The Sommelier Company , a consumer resource for wine tasting and education.One common misunderstanding, he says, is to think that cheap wine is uniformly unacceptable. “Red wine at the lowest prices is often bad experience of non-distinguished blend wine,” he says. “[tweet_Quote: display="Sparkling #wine offers some great values at the $5 level, including Spanish Cava and German Sekt. #wineswap #money"]Sparkling wine offers some great values at the $5 level, including Spanish Cava and German Sekt[/tweet_Quote: ] . White wines in that price range are usually disappointing, but Sauvignon Blanc from New Zealand can be amazing exception.” Drink this instead of that [caption id="attachment_781" align="" width="1872"] Sommelier Jörn Kleinhans drinking on the job. But that's OK. Photo: Jörn Kleinhans[/caption]Kleinhans also suggests these lower-priced wine swaps that introduce delightful new alternatives to your standbys:
[tweet_Quote: display="Instead of Champagne, buy French sparkling wine from Limoux ($10). #wineswap #personalfinance"]Instead of Champagne, buy French sparkling wine from Limoux ($10)[/tweet_Quote: ] . “Very few people can tell the difference, including sommeliers.” Bordeaux, Barolo and other top wines of great complexity have become very expensive, at $60+. [tweet_Quote: display="One of the greatest noble #wines in the world is from #Rioja. #wineswap"]One of the greatest noble wines in the world is from Rioja[/tweet_Quote: ] , in Spain. Rioja Gran Reserva level can be found under $25. “It's the best value among the top wines.” [tweet_Quote: display="Instead of American and French Sauvignon Blanc, try those from #NewZealand. #wine #personalfinance"]Instead of American and French Sauvignon Blanc, try those from New Zealand[/tweet_Quote: ] to find reliable and amazing Sauvignons under $10. The Marlborough appellation is a gold standard of the typical grapefruit flavors of Sauvignon Blanc, and even what you can find at the $7 level is pleasant. [tweet_Quote: display="Discover two under-appreciated countries of great value: Chile and South Africa. #wine #personalfinance"]Discover two under-appreciated countries of great value: Chile and South Africa.[/tweet_Quote: ] Chile's Carmenere grape shines with bold cassis fruit under $15 in the Colchagua Valley, and South African Cabernet Sauvignon from Stellenbosch is one of the best-kept value secrets on the wine market today. Avoid the sour disappointments of Chianti and instead go for Chianti Classico, which are actually different regions. You can find a great selection of excellent Chianti Classicos for under $20. Buy by the case [tweet_Quote: display="One way to get a fun education in #wine, and to save money doing it, is to buy a case and get a discount. #shopping"]One way to get a quick and fun education in wine, and to save money doing it, is to buy a case and get a discount.[/tweet_Quote: ] Most wine shops will let you mix it up. Kleinhans says a good variety of global classics would include: Riesling from Mosel, Germany t Sauvignon Blanc from Marlborough, New Zealand t Chardonnay from Napa, Calif. t Grenache Rosé from Provence, France t Pinot Noir from Willamette, Ore. t Sangiovese from Chianti Classico, Tuscany t Tempranillo from Rioja Gran Reserva, Spain t Cabernet Sauvignon from Bordeaux, France t Shiraz from Barossa, Australia t Malbec from Mendoza, Argentina t Nebbiolo from Piemonte, Italy t Tokay from Hungary Finally, even [tweet_Quote: display="If you’re looking for just one go-to varietal, it’s tough to go wrong with Pinot Noir. #wine #personalfinance"]if you’re looking for just one go-to varietal, Kleinhans says it’s tough to go wrong with Pinot Noir[/tweet_Quote: ] . “It is the grape that suits most occasions and most tastes. It also stands in no pairing contradictions with most dinner items,” he says. Have any other ideas on wine switches that taste great and save money? Let's continue the conversation on Twitter ( @VanessaMcGrady ) with the #wineswap hashtag!
